conclusion: The only force acting once the supports are removed is gravity.
Cloth pieces A and B start to fall straight downward due to gravity.
As they descend, cloth pieces A and B are the first objects to reach the upright blocks C, D under A; E, F under B.
Collision detection makes the falling cloths treat the blocks as solid obstacles, stopping parts of each cloth that meet the top edges of the blocks from moving downward.
The surrounding fabric keeps falling because the cloth is flexible.

The unsupported portions continue to slide and bend around the vertical faces of the blocks until all parts of the fabric either rest on the block tops, drape down the block sides, or settle on the tabletop.
Friction keeps the settled cloth from sliding off once its motion has ceased.
Air resistance is negligible compared with the gravitational force on the cloth.
Cloth A will drape over blocks C and D, coming to rest with those two blocks forming bumps under A, and the remainder of A lying on the table.
Cloth B will do the same over blocks E and F, so after everything stops you will see both cloths resting on the tabletop, each neatly covering the pair of blocks that happened to be beneath it.
